top_comment.text:
I fed my cat Alvin the cheap stuff from the grocery store and he was puking 
it up afterwards some nights. So I tried some better foods and did a lot of 
research and realized the food I was feeding him was like McDonald's and 
Ramen noodles everyday. After I switch him to Hound and Gatos, which is a 
paleolithic food (no carbs, just meat), his fur got so soft and shiny! He 
had more energy and he stopped puking up his dinner :-) (and his poop 
smelled so much less stinky) I have tried to switch my kitties to a raw 
diet but they didn't want to eat it unless I mixed in a good amount of a 
wet food they liked. I tried to gradually introduce it into their diet but 
they were being picky and I ended up have to throw away a lot of food. ﻿
top_comment.author: Laurina Biggs

comments.text: Nice to hear from someone as dedicated to her pets as we are
comments.author: Travis Biggs

comments.text: +Ayiesha Stewart thanks for the encouragement
comments.author: Travis Biggs

comments.text:
I just wanted to say it took me TWO years to get my cat to even TASTE raw! 
She wasn't even having it mixed in anything. After wasting the first bag of 
raw I decided to purchase 3 other brands (lots of companies offer small 
trial sizes) and portion them out for the freezer. I would try different 
methods every other week/month or take a break for a few months. Then one 
day I ended up putting some freeze dried Natures Variety Raw Boost chicken 
powder(she hated all other freeze dried brands!?) on straight raw and she 
gobbled it up. It was such an awesome moment! Now she goes crazy at meal 
time. You just have to find that one thing that works. The wet food that 
your feeding now is great but dont give up on the raw!
comments.author: Ayiesha Stewart

comments.text:
Love your post honey thanks for letting everyone know how important good 
food is for there pets
comments.author: Travis Biggs

comments.text:
Transitioning can be tricky, but it is worth the effort. Patience and 
persistence is the key.
comments.author: Margaret Gates

top_comment.text:
My cat Clementine is 2 years old and I've tried getting her to drink water. 
I've gotten the cat water dispenser and placing it in small bowls. However 
she will just knock it over, my cat hates water; she's clawed at my dresser 
when we've started the shower or flush the toilet or when we turn on the 
faucet . She hates water but I know she need to keep hydrate like we do. I 
don't know what to do I don't want to force her, she's my baby I feed her 
at certain times and make sure she has water but it just ends up on the 
floor what do I do?﻿
top_comment.author: Amberlynn Oliveros

comments.text:
In the last few months I've had to alternate our kitty to raw food - dry 
food - raw food (had to place her in a cattery), and I notice when she's on 
the raw food, she goes to the litter box at least 3 times a day, and her 
water is barely touched. Whereas on the dry food, she maybe goes 1-2 times 
a day and very thirsty. Perhaps the solution could be to switch to a raw 
diet to get the moisture?
comments.author: irisx

comments.text:
I haven't noticed that in my cat. We keep 3 watering holes throughout the 
house, and she is always drinking her water.
comments.author: Loya Frostwind

comments.text:
Cats naturally have a low thirst drive, which is why it is so important to 
feed them food with a high moisture content, i.e. canned or a raw diet. 
Adding a little water to the canned food is a good way to get extra fluid 
into a kitty that doesn't like to drink plain water.
comments.author: Margaret Gates

comments.text:
My cat would never drink water either.  I just mix a spoonful or two into 
her wet food.  As much as she uses the litter box, I think she is well 
hydrated.
comments.author: Buckley Hopper

top_comment.text:
#TeamCatMojoThis is exactly how diet affects your cat: 
http://buff.ly/1A8yDEX﻿
top_comment.author: Jackson Galaxy

comments.text:
Thank you so much for this video! I have been feeding my cat a grain-free, 
organic, made-in-the-USA, EXPENSIVE, dry food for four and a half of the 
five months that I have had her. I'm sure you can guess the brand. I saw 
incredible improvement. She didn't have smelly gas and her feces didn't 
smell. However, let's just say that I KNOW my cat misses bones and meat. 
I've been looking at alternative food for her, mostly because I also know 
she is overweight, even though my vet insists that she isn't (SO 
ANNOYING!), and I want her to live a REALLY long and fulfilling life. Thank 
you for this resource! You've just made Mila a happy cat! :)
comments.author: Krysta Beam

comments.text:
#TeamCatMojo  So true how the diet effects your cat. About 8 months ago I 
switched my 3 cats over to a raw diet, and wow what a difference! I'm a vet 
tech and really started to look into the nutrition and what would be best 
for my cats. After looking at all the different ingredients even in the 
Science Diets the raw came out on top. It makes so much sense to feed raw 
for the health of your cat. My guys are 5 yrs old and these past 8 months 
to me seems to be the happiest and healthiest they've ever been.
comments.author: Dawn H

top_comment.text:
We feed our baby both dry and wet food to balance his diet. My main worry 
is his dental health. Apparently that's what dry food does. We heard a lot 
of different sides anyway. Oh well   #TeamCatMojo  ﻿
top_comment.author: Genevieve Wilson

comments.text:
+Genevieve Wilson "He's fine. He hasn't died yet." In the early stages of 
sickness, everyone looks fine. People who become diabetic from poor junk 
food diets were obviously fine when they started eating nothing but junk 
food. You shouldn't wait for your cat to show obvious signs of sickness to 
stop feeding him crap he doesn't need.
comments.author: moistteabag

comments.text: Well its probably why he's throwing up so he's not fine.
comments.author: Katrina Ehrhart

comments.text: He's fine. He hasn't died yet.
comments.author: Genevieve Wilson

comments.text:
Cats are lactose intolerant and should NOT be given milk - kitten or not. 
 As for dry foods being good for teeth - that's pure BS, because dry food 
is full of carbs, which stick together.  Have a look at the back teeth of 
your cat and you'll see a build up of tarter that can be scratched off with 
your fingernail in chunks.
comments.author: OneKinKStar!

comments.text: +Katrina Ehrhart He's a kitten.
comments.author: Genevieve Wilson

comments.text:
+Genevieve Wilson I don't think you should be giving your cat milk. 
Especially an adult cat, it can cause stomach upset and diarrhea.
comments.author: Katrina Ehrhart

comments.text:
+Margaret Gates Not really, he doesn't tend to vomit much. He is a short 
hair and only vomits when we have given him too much milk.
comments.author: Genevieve Wilson

comments.text:
Dry food does nothing to help a cat's teeth, Cats only use their side teeth 
to cut food into pieces small enough to swallow. They don't actually "chew" 
the way we do - their jaws only move up and down, not side to side, so no 
chewing in that sense. You may have noticed if your cat has ever barfed up 
the dry food, it looks pretty much as it did when it went in. What cats 
need to help keep their teeth clean and gums stimulated is to really use 
those side teeth in slicing and gnawing through meat, skin, cartilage and 
bone (small ones!). This scraping action is nature's toothbrush for cats.
comments.author: Margaret Gates

top_comment.text:
What about a good canned (wet) food? I feed Blue non-grain wet food to my 
kitty and he seems to be thriving on it. I also had a cat many years ago 
who ate canned cat food and some people food and lived past 17 years. She 
was always healthy too. I just feel weird about feeding an indoor cat raw 
food....so many recalls on meats and poultry in this country due to 
parasites.﻿
top_comment.author: KerryGrl

comments.text:
+helpfulnatural Thanks. I've been feeding him bits of raw poultry and meat 
now and he loves it, hasn't gotten sick, but he will only eat small 
amounts, so I still give him cat food to supplement.
comments.author: KerryGrl

comments.text:
+helpfulnatural well, in my country, cat food is healthier than meat due to 
chemicals
comments.author: Karolina Trgalova

comments.text:
+helpfulnatural well, in my country, cat food is healthier than meat due to 
chemicals
comments.author: Karolina Trgalova

comments.text:
There are more recalls on pet food. Wet canned food is still better than 
feeding kibble. If you're concerned about feeding raw due to parasites, 
freeze the meats for at least 3 days before thawing and feeding. This will 
kill the majority of the bacteria on the meat. Cats have a very high acid 
content in their digestive system which is built exclusively to eat and 
digest raw meat so parasites is not an issue for them. An outdoor cat 
catching and eating mice, birds, etc. have a better chance at having an 
issue with parasites since they (parasites) live on wild animals, 
especially mice. Store bought meats intended as human food is very unlikely 
to pose a health risk to either you or your cat.  :)
comments.author: helpfulnatural

top_comment.text:
i want to feed a raw meat diet but don't know the correct composition of 
meat, etc to give to have the correct nutrients they need.﻿
top_comment.author: littlefurrybear410

comments.text:
+Margaret Gates +Jackson Galaxy And based on the recipe on the website do i 
used 2 capsules of bit E 400IU?
comments.author: littlefurrybear410

comments.text:
+Margaret Gates +Jackson Galaxy I have a question about the recipe on the 
website. It says 200mg of Vit B complex. I'm getting B-50 complex does that 
mean i need to use 4 capsules for the recipe?
comments.author: littlefurrybear410

comments.text:
+littlefurrybear410
Check into the articles on the site under Nutrition. The Do-It-Yourself and 
the Easy Raw Feeding articles will be helpful with info on supplements and 
commercial diets.
comments.author: Margaret Gates

comments.text:
+Margaret Gates or can i get human grade minced meat and adding up on 
supplements?
comments.author: littlefurrybear410

comments.text:
+Margaret Gates i'm feeding a commercial raw meat as part of his meal but 
still not convinced it's good enough because how much heart and organs does 
an animal have vs the number of meals they pack… i read the DIY recipe…. 
unfortunately i don't have the tools so i was thinking of getting the 
commercial one and topping up on supplements? would that be good enough? 
also where can i get the supplements from? i looked around in pet shops 
nearby and most of them don't have it.
comments.author: littlefurrybear410

comments.text:
We have a do-it-yourself recipe on the feline-nutrition.org website or you 
can feed a commercially prepared complete raw diet.
comments.author: Margaret Gates

top_comment.text:
My cat Luna, no longer in her fur body, was diagnosed with IBD (sans 
biopsy), and I was desperate for information on how to help her.  I asked 
my vet about a raw food diet, and he emphatically stated that a raw food 
diet was dangerous for her.  He was also quick to share articles published 
in vet journals with statistics backing up what he was saying.  Now, I 
understand that there is a possibility that those studies were funded by 
pet food companies.  But it is very difficult to find your way through 
conflicting information, especially when a "medical expert in cats" is 
steering you against the raw food option.﻿
top_comment.author: RhodaHarley

comments.text:
+Brook Gowin
That's so encouraging that your vet steered your toward raw.
comments.author: Joanne Nelson

comments.text:
I am so sorry the vet gave you the wrong information.  I had to research 
online and talk to specialty health food pet stores and then different 
veterinarians and I am still learning.  I think you can find a doctor for 
your pet that will know more about it and be loyal to you and your kat or 
dawg but you have to ask questions before you commit to them just as you 
would for yourself.  My vet suggested a raw meat diet for my IBD kitty, 
telling me she had read good things about the results..
comments.author: Brook Gowin

comments.text:
Let me tell you how "expert" vets are. A vet told me several years ago that 
they are now being trained how to maximize profits. That means when you 
bring your sick cat to them, they present you with $600 worth of tests you 
need to do, and if you can't afford that, they recommend euthanasia. It's 
disgusting.

My brother's cat disappeared for a day and when she came back she just 
looked at the food bowl. IOW, she was sick and fasting, which is how any 
animals recovers. The vet presented my brother with $700 worth of tests. My 
brother couldn't afford it, and on the advice of the vet, euthanized her. 
If he had just waited, she would have fasted to recovery and then resumed 
eating.

Most vets, like doctors, are experts at symptom suppression through 
chemical manipulation. They have little knowledge of health, and none of 
diet.
comments.author: Joanne Nelson

top_comment.text:
Don't automatically jump to conclusion. The raw diet absolutely must have a 
balance of the needed nutrients. Don't just throw chicken in the cat's bowl 
and call it a day. It takes a bit of time and effort on your part, which 
should be worth it given the benefits.﻿
top_comment.author: [Dragonfly] Infernal Internment

comments.text:
+ShadowFoxZorua
I have 7 cats. The oldest is 21 and has been fed this way since she was 13. 
I have four cats who are 9 and two who are 7, and they've been fed this way 
their whole lives. They seem to be in fine health. I would think that if 
the diet were deficient, it would have showed up by now.
comments.author: Joanne Nelson

comments.text:
+Joanne Nelson What Brook said. I *highly* suggest looking for recipes 
either on youtube or elsewhere on the net. That most defiantly won't be 
enough I'm afraid. Apparently it can   lead to bone deformity since it's 
deeply lacking in varied essentials like supplements for proper growth.
comments.author: [Dragonfly] Infernal Internment

comments.text:
+Joanne Nelson
Is that all you feed them?  They really do need more than just meat.
comments.author: Brook Gowin

comments.text:
I throw chicken in the cats bowl today. Tomorrow I throw chicken and some 
chicken hearts. The next day I feed ground turkey with sardines. The next 
day more chicken. Then chicken and liver. Then rabbit. Etc. No supplements. 
Most days they just get chunk chicken.
comments.author: Joanne Nelson

top_comment.text:
What about cats that are grazers, only eat a little at a time, then come 
back for more hours later? I know raw food you're not supposed to let sit 
out for any length of time as it will become rancid. That's the concern I 
have for my cat. I make sure I feed him only canned food, as he's not too 
big on drinking water either. But he's a grazer, don't think I can feed him 
raw food.﻿
top_comment.author: reds 17

comments.text:
+Brook Gowin
Are you warming the food before you give it to him? I would let him eat 
what he wants and then start spacing out the feeding. Instead of five times 
a day, move it to four times a day. Then three. Etc. (We are slaves to 
these little buggers, aren't we?) Everybody here is staring at me and 
crying, so time for breakfast.
comments.author: Joanne Nelson

comments.text:
my cat is a grazer too so I am hoping someone can give us both some 
answers.  I have been feeding him a raw meat diet since last July and am 
now his slave.  He eats 5 times a day if I'm home all day, otherwise he 
doesn't eat enough and losses weight.  It doesn't matter how much I put 
down after being gone he eats the little amount he wants and leaves the 
rest so I have to put it back in the fridge, then maybe in an hour he asks 
for more so I know it's not that he's not hungry.
comments.author: Brook Gowin

comments.text:
Is your cat a grazer by nature or because you leave kibble out all day? 
Perhaps you've just trained him to be a grazer. Switch your cat to raw and 
you might find him chowing down at mealtime.
comments.author: Joanne Nelson

top_comment.text: But if you feed your cat raw meat can't they get salmonella? ﻿
top_comment.author: Susanna mulcahy

comments.text:
That's only something to be concerned about for animals who are herbivores 
and have intestinal tracts 10 - 12 times their body length, cats are meat 
eaters, and their intestinal tract is only around 3 times their body length 
to pass decaying meat rapidly.

Meat eaters also have extremely strong hydrochloric stomach acids to digest 
the meat and kill off those kind of diseases, where as herbivores stomach 
acid is around 20x weaker.
comments.author: Gary Paton

comments.text:
You must always be careful in how you source the meat you feed, but keep in 
mind that cats are pretty resistant to normal levels of bacteria. Remember, 
they evolved eating raw meat. They have short digestive tracts - food only 
takes about 12 hours to pass through - not long enough for any bacteria 
present to multiply to dangerous levels. Compare that to a human, we take 
24 to 36 to digest our food, that is one of the reasons we are so much more 
susceptible to these kinds of bacteria. Cats also have highly acidic 
digestive systems, which make them more resistant to harmful bacteria. 
Source carefully, follow basic safe-handling procedures and feeding raw 
meat diets to cats is very safe. Take a look at the history of pet food 
recalls - salmonella keeps turning up in DRY FOODS, not raw meat diets.
comments.author: Margaret Gates

top_comment.text:
I'd be scared to feed my cat raw food because of the parasites.  Wouldn't 
that be a risk for the cat and I?  I think that would increase the chance 
of toxoplasmosis when changing the litter, wouldn't it? ﻿
top_comment.author: Sea_Shanty7

comments.text:
+MissaLVT  That's just not true!  Freezing the meats to be fed as a raw 
diet is a key part of the process because it kills the parasites.  Feeding 
raw cannot be done casually, which is why most people don't do it!  Those 
who do set up and process several months worth of foods at once, then 
freeze in serving containers that are pulled out to thaw as needed.  

Those people have been feeding their cats and dogs raw for many years, with 
great success and yet vets still discourage it.  WHY?  Perhaps it's because 
vets get a kick back when they sell that over-priced GRAIN FILLED 'science' 
pet food in their lobby!  

You may have witnessed problems with animals who have been fed raw, BUT 
that's hardly fair in consideration of ALL the problems that are attributed 
to cats and dogs being fed CRAP foods such as dry kibble without ever 
getting any wet pet food or real meat in their diet.  THAT is a much bigger 
issue and not a healthy diet for cats or for dogs, so at least be truthful 
about it.
comments.author: OneKinKStar!

comments.text:
+Mini Manta
True. Plus do you know what is the global rate of all of us who are 
carriers of toxoplasmosis and dont get ill? More than 50%! I was also 
amazed to see that.
comments.author: Stella T

comments.text:
+Mini Manta Also could be a concern for anyone with a weakened immunity, 
who suffers with a life-threatening disease, as well as young children 
and/or elderly people.  All of these people most likely would not be 
cleaning a litter box or have any contact with cat feces anyway, but still 
worth mentioning, to include with pregnant women.
comments.author: OneKinKStar!

comments.text:
Toxoplasmosis is only dangerous to pregnant women, so if you're not 
pregnant, you shouldn't be worried about it :)
comments.author: Mini Manta

comments.text:
By feeding your cat raw food the chance of getting parasites is actually 
smaller than feeding her/him canned or dry. Plus, if you're worried about 
bacteria, freeze the food first, that way you will kill most bacteria. Cats 
and dogs (especially cats) have more acids in their stomach that kill 
bacteria than humans. And the chance of getting salmonella or e.coli is 
almost non-existent, since it would be all over media if something like 
that turned up somewhere. Being afraid of the last two in the raw meat is 
like being afraid if your outdoor cat has rabies.
comments.author: vojvodkinja

comments.text:
+Sea_Shanty7 All you need to do is practise proper hygiene. Educate 
yourself on how to properly handle and store raw meat. Make sure you freeze 
and make bulk. Make sure you properly clean your hands before and after you 
have handled food. Use gloves if you want to but it's not necessary.
comments.author: Neko Naiami

comments.text: +Margaret Gates Interesting, thanks.
comments.author: Sea_Shanty7

comments.text:
+Sea_Shanty7 Things like worms are really only a concern with things that 
your cat might be catching outdoors and eating. Very unlikely to be a 
problem with a raw meat diet as the meats used are human-grade.
comments.author: Margaret Gates

comments.text: +Margaret Gates Thanks, and what about other worms?
comments.author: Sea_Shanty7

comments.text:
+Sea_Shanty7
To get the toxoplasmosis parasite is actually not that easy. You have to 
ingest (as in EAT) the cysts at a certain point in their development, you 
can't get them from a cat bite or a scratch. As long as you practice good 
hygiene, washing your hands after cleaning the litterbox, you are very 
unlikely to have a problem.
comments.author: Margaret Gates

comments.text:
+Assassins Angel I searched the website and found some info on parasites 
and worms related to wild/raw food.
comments.author: Sea_Shanty7

comments.text:
That's fair. Maybe they have more information on that on the website in the 
info box :)
comments.author: Assassins Angel

comments.text:
+Assassins Angel I'd still be worried.  She could lick or bite me and I 
could get them that way too.  The video was informative, but I still feel 
unsure.
comments.author: Sea_Shanty7

comments.text:
I think if you practice good hygiene when feeding/cleaning the litter you 
should be fine
comments.author: Assassins Angel

top_comment.text:
My cat needs dental specified food, so correct me if I am wrong but raw 
meat would not help my cats teeth or eliminate any plaque build up and dry 
food is best for her situation, She has been on dry food since she was one 
because if she was on wet food she could lead to having gingivitis. but 
like I said correct me if I am wrong :)﻿
top_comment.author: Ashleigh Windrow

comments.text:
It is a fallacy that dried food keeps their teeth clean. It is loaded with 
carbs which coat the teeth with plaque and promotes bacterial growth. It is 
the same with humans. Eating a high carb diet causes tooth decay.
You can safely give your cat RAW chicken necks. They MUST be raw. This will 
help keep her teeth clean, as she gnaws on the bones. And she will get 
awesome nutrition from eating the meat and bones.
FYI - raw bones break up into small cube like pieces and are safe to 
ingest. Cooked bones break up into slivers. This can hurt your cat. So 
never feed cooked bones.
comments.author: Mekabra

comments.text:
+Ashleigh Windrow   Like I said, look at the back teeth and you'll see 
that's wrong.
comments.author: OneKinKStar!

comments.text:
I got told by the vet to give her dry food as wet food causes tartar build 
up. which is why old cat who have lived off wet food have so much tarter 
build up, :)
comments.author: Ashleigh Windrow

comments.text:
Dry food is full of carbs, that stick together and stick to their teeth. 
 Pull back your cat's mouth and look at those back teeth and you'll likely 
see tarter built up so thick you can scratch it off in chunks with your 
fingernail!  I'm serious.
comments.author: OneKinKStar!

comments.text:
dry food with all those carbs rots your cats teeth.  that is why so many 
cats are on dental plans now.
comments.author: patricia mcdermott

comments.text:
+Beauty Psycho I'm going to get a plaque breaker to put in her water, its 
been highly requested to me so i'm going to try that out, because cats 
don't always like their teeth being cleaned:)
comments.author: Ashleigh Windrow

comments.text:
Cat can develop gingivitis when on dry food diet too (mine did). I think 
the best way to care for cat's teeth is by brushing them with cat's 
toothpaste every day.
comments.author: Beauty Psycho

top_comment.text:
#TeamCatMojo This wk's ep of Cat Mojo is about raw food for cats. 
http://buff.ly/Y97ILE﻿
top_comment.author: Jackson Galaxy

comments.text:
+richard waite
If you've ever witnessed a cat eating a mouse or small bird you'll know why

those little bones inside them.

Can't offer you any advice tho, sorry...
comments.author: DrSpooglemon

Thanks for this video +Jackson Galaxy, however... What if your cat likes

Regards,
Paul

top_comment.text:
This video appears to be exclusively comparing raw food to dry food diets. 
Will you be doing a second part, comparing canned foods (preferably the 
range from supermarket brands to the high quality all-natural products so 
available now) to raw? I'd love to see a sequel! How about home-cooking? 
Thanks!﻿
top_comment.author: Gayze Nastasi

comments.text:
Probably because meat is more expensive than brown rice and sweet potatoes 
that's why they use it as a filler. Anyway, I am happy that I am not 
feeding my furry friends GMO corn and meat by-product and dry pebbles like

comments.author: Beauty Psycho

comments.text:
I feed my two cats natural wet/canned food that is grain free (Natural 
Balance or Halo) that I buy from health store. Unfortunately, what I've got 
from this video is: the food I feed is much much better than feeding dry 
food and commercial brands BUT it still contains vegetables which are not

duck and carrots.
comments.author: Beauty Psycho

comments.text:
+Paige Hansen Yes, but that compares canned food to dry food. My thoughts 
were that I would like to see a comparison of canned food to raw.
comments.author: Gayze Nastasi

comments.text:
Actually, Margaret mentions that canned wet food is even a better 
alternative to dry food at 6:43 in the episode
comments.author: Paige Hansen

comments.text: I agree!  Jackson, would love to hear more comparing raw and wet.  Thanks!
comments.author: Michel T

top_comment.text:
Because of constant stomach problems I changed to a raw meat diet but my 6 
year old male has decided that he doesn't need to drink any fluids of any 
kind no matter what I offer him.  He has been to the doc numerous times for 
subcutaneous fluids.  His stools are hard and turn to dust when crushed and 
this urine waste is about half of what it used to be.  What can I do beside 
give him subcutaneous fluids?﻿
top_comment.author: Brook Gowin

comments.text:
+Joanne Nelson
I just found out that it is normal for his stools to be crusty but he is 
also dehydrated by his doctors standards and there is very little urine in 
his box so this is why he needs the sub-Q fluids.  He has many medical 
issues but he is getting the fluids because of his dehydration, this 
started with the raw food diet.  He wasn't dehydrated when he was on kibble 
but then we had other medical issues.  He stopped eating last week because 
his tummy was upset and I fed him the Rad Cat brand raw diet to get him to 
eat again.  Now he isn't dehydrated and his poo looks totally different, it 
isn't crusty at all. ??? why is this??  How often should he have a bowel 
movement on raw meat?
comments.author: Brook Gowin

comments.text:
Is your cat ill? Are you giving him subQ only because of his stools? Raw 
diet stools are hard and turn to dust when crushed. That's normal. Stools 
are sticky from the gluten in grains. Stop eating grains yourself and 
you'll seldom need toilet paper.

My cats hardly ever touch the water bowl. When I buy raw chicken hearts or 
chicken from the store, I pour the liquid onto a plate for them to drink. 
They LOVE it. They love blood. When you feed them raw, they get most of 
their liquid from their food. If you feed them kibble, they'll have to 
drink a lot of water and end up peeing a lot.
comments.author: Joanne Nelson

top_comment.text:
When I adopted my cat they told me he'd be on a special diet his whole life 
due to struvite crystals so they handed me a bag of special dry food from a 
vet.  I fed it to him for a while until he started to vomit and itching 
like mad.  So I went to an all natural pet store and got their take on it. 
 They told me I should go raw, but I needed to ween him off the dry stuff 
first.  They helped me find a similar food for the same problem and I 
switched him over to an all natural, grain free food.  Over the next few 
months I went from that to wet food and then finally to raw meat (RadCat). 
 My cat is very very picky so this process was very slow.  Now his fur is 
super shiny, he's very active, he lost all his extra weight, and best off 
all he doesn't have problems going to the bathroom anymore, and no more 
struvite crystals.   He is just so much healthier in general since the 
switch.  I have no regrets switching him to the raw diet and I have been 
recommending it to friends and family.﻿
top_comment.author: Mithmëoi Art

comments.text:
Jennifer, a raw meat diet isn't just store bought raw meat.  Your kitty 
needs a food that is balanced for a feline, you can find out more 
information from a good specialty pet store or your vet.  You can purchase 
Raw Meat Diet foods that have the added ingredients your cat will need and 
all you need to do is dethaw and feed or you can make your own but to buy 
all the vitamins and other nutrients is a big investment at first. Raw meat 
by itself will not be enough to sustain your kitty.
comments.author: Brook Gowin

comments.text: +ShadowFoxZorua  thank you.
comments.author: Jennifer Dodd

comments.text:
+Jennifer Dodd Apologies if an explanation is unnecessary with the 3 month 
gap, but if you want to feed a cat a raw diet, make sure it's balanced. A 
raw diet can be the healthiest meal for a feline companion, but it has to 
be done right, or it'll become the worst. Without a balance of needed 
nutrients, raw diets have been said to cause skeletal deformity.
comments.author: [Dragonfly] Infernal Internment

comments.text:
+Genesis Whitmore
 What exactly do you feed them? Fish, chicken, beef? Do you give them 
anything else, or just raw meat?
comments.author: Jennifer Dodd

comments.text:
YES!  My cats eat raw and they're amazingly healthy.  They have bright 
white teeth and glossy coats... not to mention the litter box isn't as 
stinky!
comments.author: Genesis Whitmore

top_comment.text:
So what exactly should you do if you live in Europe"Norway" where there are 
no ready made raw food with the proper vitamins and minerals being sold??
On top of that some minerals like taurine are restricted thanks to the 
silly laws in this country, which means that you cannot get the supplements 
needed if you cook the food from scratch either.
I guess our only choice is to let our cats suffer on the toxic commericial 
crap food?

So my question now is what would be the least unhealthy diet if I cannot 
aquire the supplements? Would a raw diet combined with commericial wet food 
ensure that my cat gets the required minerals/vitamins?﻿
top_comment.author: bloxyman22

comments.text:
+OneKinKStar!
On the east cost, you can order from hare-today.com. They have an amazing 
selection of affordable raw food products for pets, and they ship anywhere.
comments.author: Joanne Nelson

comments.text: +OneKinKStar! "Do a Googly," HAHAHAHA awesome phrase.
comments.author: Lea Stretch

comments.text:
+bloxyman22  I recall reading about ordering rabbit meat online several 
years ago - the last time I was considering this raw feed thing.  Of course 
shipping is a cost to consider, so ordering in bulk makes that hurt less. 
 I'm sorry I don't recall the name of the company though, but maybe you can 
do a Googly and find it or others who ship frozen meats.
comments.author: OneKinKStar!

comments.text:
+CelestialLoveKitty
This might sound silly, but there are no butchers around here either. The 
crappy supermarket food has sadly made them extinct in many towns and 
cities since Norwegians care more about prize then quality. ;(
comments.author: bloxyman22

comments.text:
+bloxyman22 I use very few supplements, I am in Italy and we also have laws 
on vitamins, minerals and Taurine, thus I buy online, I got taurine from 
zooplus.de. yet you can use real heart meat to replace taurine, sheep heart 
or the beef one, cause they are bigger than chicken heart. And store 
shorter period of time in freezer. If you are quite close to Sweden, and 
can drive there, I think you can find something in Sweden as well. My 
Swedish friend buy "cat sausage" that is made of human grade used meat and 
bones from butcher, and add extra heart meat without adding taurine, they 
have also vitamins and taurine supplements for pet. If you can, get Bozita 
that is rather handy for you I think as it is a Swedish brand. Hope this 
help.
comments.author: Lou Eusebio

comments.text:
+Margaret Gates
Thanks for the reply. I will try to research and see what i can source, but 
in general they are very strict with most vitamins and minerals here.
But until I can source the supplements needed could I alternatve with one 
day raw food and the other day wet foods or will that do more harm than 
good as well? I know it is not optimal but neither is feeding 
overproccessed commericial cat food. :\
comments.author: bloxyman22

comments.text:
All of the supplements called for in the recipe on the Feline Nutrition 
site are human-grade and should be available in a vitamin store or online. 
If you cannot locate taurine, then you can make sure to feed some extra 
heart (hearts are rich in taurine). Chicken, turkey, beef, pork, sheep or 
other mammal heart is fine.

We don't recommend combining raw and cooked in the same meal, as the cooked 
food slows down the digestion of the raw food.
comments.author: Margaret Gates

top_comment.text:
I totally agree. But what to do when your cat is used to dry food and would 
never EVER even touch meat. My siamese was just like that.﻿
top_comment.author: marvincontendo

comments.text: Yeah, this makes sense. Thank you!
comments.author: marvincontendo

comments.text:
You still can change its preferences but slowly, smart way. First, try to 
give your cat a small piece of wet canned food (fingernail size maybe?). 
You can put it into a bowl with dry food as it was only a mistake. If its 
not working try to put the same portion of canned food onto the cat paw to 
make the cat lick the food. He/she should get used to new texture and 
flavor of the food, do it day by day for a week or so. After a few days try 
to put the small portion of wet food into the bowl with dry food. Week by 
week you can slowly change the proportions of dry and wet food in the bowl 
till you will have a wet food with only a few pieces of dry (kind of 
topping) and later - only the wet food. Then you can try to put raw meat 
(again - small portion) into the wet food and follow the same routine as 
described above. It may take several months but it should work.
comments.author: Laidee T.

top_comment.text:
I wouldn't mind feeding my cats on a raw meat diet but the biggest issue I 
have is money. Isn't it expensive feeding your cat raw meat? Is there a way 
I could do it with out breaking my bank? Also where do you get the 
supplements for the meat?﻿
top_comment.author: Syraa

comments.text:
You can include foods like chicken wings, lamb heart, kidney, rabbit. I 
find feeding my cat  meat (I do both raw and cooked) can be cheap. Check 
out a good butcher and  get them to save you oddments like chicken wings. 
My butcher gives me free oddments of liver and chicken carcass for almost 
free (I boil up the chicken carcass and take the bones out).
comments.author: Carly Stevens

comments.text:
If you make your own, it can work out about the same or lower cost than a 
good-quality canned food. Plus, you have the added benefit of knowing 
exactly what's in the food. The supplements are human-grade supplements 
(please see the Do-It-Yourselfers article in the Nutrition section of the 
website for a recipe) or you can use a pre-mix. You would need to get a 
grinder, but that will pay for itself in fewer vet bills!
comments.author: Margaret Gates

top_comment.text:
Maybe you've addressed this already, but what about if you're vegan? Where 
would you get the raw ingredients for your cat? I'm vegan and I want to do 
the best for my cat, but I also don't want to support factory farming and 
all of that.﻿
top_comment.author: Kino McFarland

comments.text:
+Kino McFarland Kino, I do understand veganism since I was once a vegan and 
have studied it extensively. I gave you a link to a place where you can 
source pasture-raised meats.
comments.author: Joanne Nelson

comments.text:
I know where meat for kibble and canned food comes from... the same place 
all meat comes from. I know that Jackson Galaxy is vegan, so this question 
was really for him... for someone that actually understands veganism.
comments.author: Kino McFarland

comments.text:
Where do you think meat for kibble or canned food comes from? If you're 
dedicated to feeding raw, go to Eatwild.com and find a local farmer who 
raises his animals with care.
comments.author: Joanne Nelson

top_comment.text:
I have 23 cats.. due to this, we do use dry food (purina cat chow indoor 
formula works best for us), however, I do mix with can food and RAW 
HAMBURGER MEAT! They love it. Added with a gel vitamin supplement and/or 
antibiotics keeps my cats healthy and some of them quite plump :)﻿
top_comment.author: Tina Lynn

comments.text:
None are overweight.. and they all get exercise regularly.. by plump, I 
mean healthy and fluffy..
comments.author: Tina Lynn

comments.text: Call it whatever you want to, but a 'plump' cat is not healthy.
comments.author: OneKinKStar!

top_comment.text:
It would be really nice but the problem is that dry food is much much 
cheaper than raw meat diets to the casual owner. Not everyone has a nice 
butcher to go to and get personal meats. Many just have to go to a local 
Walmart, which arent accustomed to custom orders, because they dont get 
many to begin with. Then theres the nutritional needs of the cat that seem 
complex to the casual owner. Taurine, crude fats, crude protien, etc get 
thrown around and not everyone knows exactly what those are, whats the 
difference, whats better, and how much. Defaulting to the "raw food" 
available in stores packaged specifically for cats.. well... right now they 
are reaping the benefits of a small market, and prices are very high. Not 
only that, they still add certain items in there that cats dont need to 
help fill the space, reaping an even greater monetary income versus the 
cost of mass producing. 

What people also really misunderstand about dry food... is the hydration. 
Raw meats (and bones if you think about bone marrow) have a certain amount 
of liquid, water, or general fluids within. Cats get so dehydrated off 
water and dry food because their normal partial-liquid-intake (meat) is 
denied. If you could choose between eating a bowl of soup, or drinking 4 
cups of water, chances are youd choose the soup. Its smaller, easier to get 
down in one sitting, and tastes better. Makes sense for cats too. 

That being said, I cant afford a totally raw-meat diet personally, myself, 
but I do the best I can. They have dry food if theyre hungry as a backup, 
they get at least a can of wet food a day (to share, because, I dont 
understand how they think 1 cat can eat a whole can in 1 setting. Mine cant 
even eat the whole can split between them, and I have some BIG cats!), and 
theyll get meat cuttings whenever I prepare meat. The cuttings are probably 
about 50-70% fat and the other 30-50% actual meat that was trimmed as well. 
Some like it, some dont. Just like some will also eat leaves off 
salad-ingredients I buy and grass. Even with this half and half.. their 
poop still stinks to high heaven LOL. ﻿
top_comment.author: Riko Lime

comments.text:
And then you also have to look at past experiences with other dry foods. I 
remember one.. what was it.. Wellness, Goodness, something "awesome"-ness 
brand, that was very highly recommended because it had natural meats and 
veggies. 

Last I heard about it, it was being recalled and cancelled because it was 
causing pets to DIE from food poisoning. Something about one of their 
ingredients causing liver/kidney failure. So yeahhhhh cost =/= best food.
comments.author: Riko Lime

comments.text:
+Jessica Cejnar IHills or Royal Canine are very poor brands but are 
recommend by many veterinarians because they get a kick-back. If that is 
your budget I suggest you do a lot of online research for a GOOD dry food 
and don't buy it at your vet's but a specialty shop because a raw met diet 
is at least two to three times that much.  There are several specialty pet 
shops that carry complete raw diets in Portland one is Green Dog on 42nd 
and Fremont where I buy mine because they have been so very helpful and 
another shop is Pets On Broadway who has excellent prices.  I've only been 
to the last shop once, each of these shops carry a little different brands.
comments.author: Brook Gowin

comments.text:
A 3 pound bag of dry food (Hill's) costs me between $10 and $13 depending 
on if I buy the regular or go for the oral health one. And it usually takes 
my cat a month to go through it. I've also started feeding my cat wet food, 
typically half a can twice a day, so that's also probably $10-15 a month.
comments.author: Jessica Cejnar

comments.text:
+Brook Gowin Well all the proper recipes Ive seen that come highly 
recommended, require a meat grinder (which I dont own and is costly). I 
only make minimum wage. A bag of dry cat food (10$) lasts several months 
for me.
comments.author: Riko Lime

comments.text:
+Brook Gowin Where in Oregon do you live and where do you get your cat's 
food? I live just south of Oregon in Smith River.
comments.author: Jessica Cejnar

comments.text:
+Brook Gowin
PS.  I buy it pre-made and frozen
comments.author: Brook Gowin

comments.text:
+RikoLime
My kitty weights 10 lbs and I feed him two different brands of raw food, he 
gets tired of one flavor so I switch them.  I average about $45 a month for 
his basic food.  I live in Oregon
comments.author: Brook Gowin

comments.text:
Study's have shown that felines get most of their water intake from meat 
and have a low thirst drive naturally. Granted a cat make drink a bit more 
water when on a dry food diet but not near as much to what they need to 
drink. Its at a drastically lower rate than a cat who is on a canned/raw 
meat diet. Hence why bladder issued occur more frequently in cats who are 
on a hard food diet. Please have a look at www.catinfo.org its where i 
learned a lot of information on feline nutrition (and id bet my last dollar 
the Vet. who wrote the site is the one she seen the presentation from).﻿

P.S. My cat eats 6oz. of canned food a day, but I split up the meal into 
two servings of 3oz. Youre right it isnt eaten in one sitting he eats it 
over the course of the day, but its typically all gone by the next serving. 
Oh, and I pay aprox. $65/month for his pet food since I order online and in 
bulk. At www.petfooddirect.com if youre wondering.
comments.author: CurlyFro

comments.text:
Ive just combed through their site on cat nutrition and the recipes 
involved. "Ideally, you want to get meat that is antibiotic and hormone 
free, and free-range if possible. Get organic meats if you can" these are 
very expensive compared to other items that we (humans) would even consume. 
"You definitely want to get liver"-"Preferably from a free-range animal, 
with no hormones or antibiotics used." - again, "expensive" compared to the 
norm used, and Ive only ever seen 1 package/brand of liver in my local 
stores that I shop at, which leads me to believe it would be hard to find. 
"chicken hearts, which can be difficult to source" - the site says they can 
be found most often at "ethnic food stores" or "Korean supermarkets". I 
have no Korean supermarkets near me, and ethnic food stores are rare here. 
Plus, if the point is to get mostly antibiotic/hormone free, and free range 
meats, then why skimp on this ingredient and "not care" about the specifity 
of it simply because its hard to find, which it is. "Buy free-range eggs, 
preferably organic". At this point, the recipe for "raw meat diet" for cats 
eats/costs easily three times as much. o.o

Then theres all the nutrients needed. Taurine, salmon oil (which I know is 
expensive. I just bought this bottle about 1/3 the size of a coke can, and 
it cost me 10$ - imagine having to buy enough for the recipe! This was a 
tiny bottle - cheaper than the capsules as well, to which the recipe calls 
for all capsules), Vitamin B complex, E, Lite Salt with Iodine, and 
Psyllium Husk Powder. 

I understand the broken down cost per-meal is "cheaper" for each resulting 
pound, but the point is that you cant just buy "half a capsule" of salmon 
oil for the recipe. No, you have to buy the bottle of capsules. For 
everything. Buying 1 chicken thigh is far more expensive per thigh than 
buying 10, but buying 10 you pay 7 or 8 times the price. 

So actually looking at the recipe and ingredients, I can verily argue that 
it can quite possibly be far too "expensive" for the casual pet owner to 
get started. Were talking maybe 20$ a month for the "best" dry food, 
versus.. well lets say all vitamins cost the same as the salmon oil so.. 6 
vitamins (60$). The chicken for the recipe might cost 15$ for a set of 6-8 
depending on the size, each recipe set requires chicken hearts at 3$ a 
pound (I didnt look at the "set" prices for those), Liver (again, I dont 
buy this regularly so I didnt look at the costs, but it says nearly 3$ a 
pound), and eggs, which are cheap 4$ total. The site says for a 10 lb cat, 
about 4 oz of this food is the right amount, but the bare minimum recipe 
itself only makes 17 oz. Theres no way to tell how many chicken hearts or 
livers the recipe uses, because it all goes by oz. So, I will assume it 
takes at least 1 chicken heart. The recipe only makes about 4 days of 
food.. for one cat. So on top of the 60$ in vitamins, and all the meat 
costs, the initial recipe only makes a few days of food for one cat (to 
which I will note a lot of owners dont just have one cat, they usually have 
two or three - which makes this a 2 day meal recipe). Lets not forget this 
whole process requires that the owner have a MEAT GRINDER capable of also 
grinding bones. This can easily cost 150$ for a decent quality machine that 
wont break down after a few months of constant cat-food use. To which I 
would say, you would want to get the higher quality one, simply because 
this cat diet requires constant use of the grinder. 

Maybe this helps explain why it would be hard for the "casual" owner to 
BEGIN this process. Im sure once the process is started, those initial 
costs disappear, as the rest of it is using items you mostly already have, 
and maintaining your stockpile of them - but hopefully this kind of 
explains it. 

Again this is coming from an owner of several cats, who wishes she could 
afford a 100% raw meat diet, but has actually looked at the costs, and 
understands right now, it is not feasible.

TL;DR Version: Initial costs of items/ingredients/machines (vitamins at 10$ 
each, meat grinder at 150$, and "hard to find" meat items such as chicken 
hearts, rabbit, and liver) to begin a raw meat diet are far more expensive 
than maintaining a dry/canned food diet - which is most likely the reason 
so many people feed their cats dry/canned instead of converting to this 
healthier "raw meat diet".
comments.author: Riko Lime

comments.text:
+Morgan Matthews Funny story... my eldest cat who would ONLY eat dry food, 
and rarely (I do mean rarely.. shes 10, and has only done it 5 times 
overall I can recall) would eat canned food if it had egg and tuna in it - 
but, was feeding the others some raw meat, and one piece landed on her 
back/hip and stuck there. She got frantic, reached back there with her 
mouth, and bit it to pull it off. She found out she liked the taste after 
that. Now, shes always begging for meat. 

Not that Id recommend that but.. sometimes you just gotta get em to taste 
it somehow!
comments.author: Riko Lime

comments.text:
High quality cat food is still full of shit and most probably not as good 
for your cat as a combination of that and meat with added shit. A good way 
of getting your cat to eat raw meat is just by adding little bits into 
their normal food and increasing the amount every day.
comments.author: Morgan Matthews

comments.text:
It's also better than thinking that feeding your cat nothing but Friskies 
and Meow Mix will be sufficient. It's the same thing with me. I don't have 
a butcher I can go to to get organ meat or specialty cuts. There's Walmart 
and Safeway and that's it. Plus, the meat that is sold is generally full of 
hormones and other additives that I wouldn't want to give to my cat. I 
could probably get my cat to eat a raw diet, but as I said I'm on a budget 
and cats are finicky, especially mine when it comes to people food. I feed 
her high quality food that fits with my budget.
comments.author: Jessica Cejnar

comments.text:
+Morgan Matthews Thats great! But I notice you said Euro.. I think in the 
US, in most places, its not that easy. In my town, we only really have 
three places to get decent meat: Walmart, Kroger (like a smaller Walmart), 
and HEB (like a walmart, but has totally different "brands" of the same 
items). Theres no butchers, or butchery, or fancy place to buy the cut-offs 
from meat, and Ive never seen nor heard of anyone getting them from Walmart 
(Im not sure they even have a price for it, and their policy may be to not 
sell it period due to health risks). I have tried, its not just stating 
blindingly. I asked once, and they looked at me like I was crazy. A pack of 
chicken breasts (for me at least) yields maybe 7 breasts, and costs 10$ or 
more (which considering other food costs, is "expensive"). Im sure if you 
had one cat, this would be manageable to an extent, but I personally have 
more than one, and buying enough for each one to feel full and not hungry 
would take quite a bit. Thats not even mentioning some like bacon, or red 
meat, or pork, and not chicken. Some like fish and dry food and nothing 
else. I also do buy sale meats on the rare occasion I see the min the 
supermarkets, but I think the difference is areas. If your areas has a 
butchery or place where you can get custom meats and orders, and the spare 
bits, then its great, but not every place has them. Thats all I mean to 
explain. 

But I think the important thing here is that we are well-aware of the "raw 
meat diet" for cats, and we know how important it is, and are trying to get 
as close to it as we can. Its better than not knowing at all and not trying 
at all.
comments.author: Riko Lime

comments.text:
I am poor as all hell and I can afford a raw meat diet for my cat. The way 
I find meat is by going to supermarkets near closing time and getting sale 
meats and such and then freezing. Also going to the butchers and getting 
"off cuts", the bits of meat that are wasted when cutting meat. I spend 
about 6 euro a week on food for my kitty. Things like organs and bits of 
meat that are important for cats are not usually that expensive and things 
like chicken fillets can be bought for really cheap. Raw feeding is not 
that expensive, it's just more work than buying a box of dry food. A lot of 
you people are giving up before you've ever tried. If you care for and love 
your cat, make an effort, if it turns out that you cannot afford to raw 
feed then, at least you can say you tried.
comments.author: Morgan Matthews

comments.text:
I buy the best food I can afford for my cat as well. I don't buy her cheap 
commercially available cat food unless I am absolutely out of cat food and 
she needs to eat.
comments.author: Jessica Cejnar

comments.text:
Consider this - Pay now for better food, or pay later for medical expenses. 
That is the choice. I do not make a lot of money. In fact there is always 
too much month left at the end of my pay check. But I value the health of 
my cat as much as I value my own. I buy the best food available for my cat. 
As a result he is healthier at 15 than he was at 8.
comments.author: Mekabra

comments.text:
+Jessica Cejnar The only (really) sad thing about dry food and dry snack 
foods tho is they treat them with a special chemical / item. I read once 
its akin to Parmesan cheese (or rather, Parmesan cheese has it as well in 
it naturally). They coat the dry food in it. It smells SOOOo delicious to 
cats, which is why they may seem to love dry foods (especially things like 
Party Mix, or the other snack-y ones). So you never can truly know, with 
dry food at least, if your cat really likes it, or if they just super 
coated it with this tasty substance.. :/

That being said, I do now buy my cats... I think its Purina Naturals? Idk, 
the food is very tiny (looks like kitten food), and is a green color. At 
first I did it because its green (Im tired of red puke stains on my tan 
carpets, and green seems to not stain it) and tiny, so it makes me feel 
better when they dont sit there and wince as they crunch big pieces apart, 
but they seem to really love it. We call it "Kitty Cookies". But I even use 
this as "snack" food. I put out a decent amount (maybe a cup, maybe cup and 
half) when they get that 1 can they share that i described. Mostly because 
there is 1 that absolutely refuses to eat canned food, but I want her to 
still eat and enjoy a snack with the others.
comments.author: Riko Lime

comments.text:
+RikoLime Yeah, I usually free feed my cat. And she doesn't eat very much 
at one time, typically just a few bites here and there. Once I fed her 
Purinas because my vet was closed and I was absolutely out of catfood and 
my cat simply inhaled that food. She couldn't get enough of it.
comments.author: Jessica Cejnar

comments.text:
+Jessica Cejnar Well it sounds fine to me, as a fellow "best I can afford" 
pet owner here. Mine (I have several), ususally free feed on dry food 
(theyll fight with eachother if I try to schedule feed times, because the 
hungrier ones steal from the slower ones) - and about every day, or every 
other day, they share a can of wet food. They have really nice clean water 
fountains to drink from, and if they want, I let them drink from sinks, or 
even my own drinks (tea and such - hey, kitties like flavored water too!). 
Its not a "raw diet" but its similar to what you say you do, and it works 
out pretty well in my opinion.. and its manageable!
comments.author: Riko Lime

comments.text:
+RikoLime I've been feeding my cat dry food (Healthy Advantage, which was 
prescribed by my vet) and an occasional can of wet food. I'm on a budget 
and there's no way I can afford the commercial raw meat diet products or 
purchase the quality meat free of hormones, etc. that my cat needs. I 
thought that I'm feeding my cat as quality of a diet as I can afford, but 
apparently not.
comments.author: Jessica Cejnar

top_comment.text:
Which is more economically friendly? 
Coming from a college student!﻿
top_comment.author: Fine Fina

comments.text:
+Dorothy Menefee You don't need grinders, just a meat cleaver, a cutting 
board, and a dead animal. :)
comments.author: Joanne Nelson

comments.text:
+Ayiesha Stewart This reply was helpful to me too. I live in a small 
apartment and have a 4 mo old kitten that I'm currently feeding grain-free 
canned food and do want to try adding some raw food to the diet, but I 
really have not much of an idea of how to do it and don't have space for 
any grinders or big equipment.
comments.author: Dorothy Menefee

comments.text:
People who are able to keep raw the cheapest usually have freezer space to 
buy meat in bulk and feed the Raw Prey model way(whole cuts of muscle 
meat,organ,bone). That is the cheapest. My cat wont always eat bigger 
chunks so I buy whole ground carcasses online and add supplements. I dont 
have a grinder to do it myself which would save $ but I also don't have 
extra freezer space in my apartment...so a grinder isn't worth the cost. 
Look into pre-mix raw brands. For most of those all you add is muscle meat, 
depending on where you live and the cost of meat that could be an option. 
Also talk with local butchers! Someone might be able to get whole ground 
chicken or rabbit carcasses. Catinfo. org and Dr. Lisa who runs that site 
is another great source of info. She has a section on canned foods she says 
'I would much rather see a cat eat an all-by-product canned food 
than any dry food" . That means Friskies wet food is better than say Orijen 
dry food. I totally believe that. Even just eliminating all dry food and 
doing a wet diet of cheaper brands with better brands is a step in the 
right direction. I know some who feed raw supplemented by cheaper wet 
brands to keep cost down. Start by figuring out how much you can spend on 
cat food and see what works within that budget.
comments.author: Ayiesha Stewart

top_comment.text:
Hi, My small female fertil Holy Birma has pancreatitis and is on a low fat 
diet because of that - ,we also have a large castrated male (also Holy 
Birma) that benefit from the low fat diet - would both of them benefit from 
a raw meat diet?﻿
top_comment.author: Maria Jansson

comments.text: Thank you - will do - and thanks for quick reply!
comments.author: Maria Jansson

comments.text:
Yes, both of them would benefit from a raw meat diet. Please work with your 
veterinarian to adjust the diet to meet your cats' individual situations.
comments.author: Margaret Gates

top_comment.text:
I have seven cats, one of them has urinary tract problem he had crystasl 
and blocked his system twice. the vet said we have to feed him C/D dry 
food, i tried to feed him meat ( not raw but boiled chicken etc.) the vet 
said i shouldn't because he has to get some vitamins etc. from the c/d food 
that is not in the chicken i feed him. I don't think that is true but 
anyway i tried the raw food but 3 of them doesn't eat it whatever i do. How 
can i change the diets of the ones that are so used to the dry food ? i 
mixed it with dry food it doesn't matter when they smell the meat they go 
away :(﻿
top_comment.author: Sedef Selay

comments.text:
If you have a Facebook, I'm part of a group of raw feeders. The group is 
called The Raw Feeding Community and has two Dobermans as their cover 
photo. If you would like a website, 
http://www.rawfedcats.org/practicalguide.htm is one to look at. This is 
what they all say for new comers who are looking for cats to switch since 
it is very difficult to have your cat switched to raw.
comments.author: Liz Sullivan

comments.text: +Sedef Selay yeah I can imagine!  Hope it works out! :)
comments.author: Mithmëoi Art

comments.text:
+Mithmëoi Art thank you so much, i hope i will be able to switch them, 
especially the six of them wants the sick one's food and that one want 
others' it's chaos twice a day in the house :))
comments.author: Sedef Selay

comments.text:
My cat had problems with urinary infections and struvite crystals.  He's a 
super picky eater so switching him over to raw food was tricky.  It took me 
probably 4-5 months to fully switch him over to raw meat, but so worth it. 
 He hasn't had any problems since then.  :)  I wish you the best with your 
kitties!
comments.author: Mithmëoi Art

comments.text:
Also try ready this page, it talks about urinary tract problems and C/D 
isn't so great: http://www.catinfo.org/?link=urinarytracthealth
comments.author: Sapphire Luna

comments.text:
+Margaret Gates thanks ! i will be spending some time on the site obviously 
:)
comments.author: Sedef Selay

comments.text:
+littlefurrybear410 Check into the articles on the site under Nutrition. 
The Do-It-Yourself and the Easy Raw Feeding articles will be helpful with 
info on supplements and commercial diets.
comments.author: Margaret Gates

comments.text:
+Margaret Gates i want to switch but have no idea how to compose it well so 
they get all the nutrients they need, i.e taurine.
comments.author: littlefurrybear410

comments.text:
Hi Sedef, this is Margaret. Check out the article on transitioning your 
cats to a raw diet that we have in the Nutrition section. The key is to 
take it slow and be patient. It's worth the effort!
comments.author: Margaret Gates

top_comment.text:
What if you have a cat who has kidney/urinary issues? How would this type 
of diet be for them as opposed to food such as Hills Prescription Diet?﻿
top_comment.author: squirrel1ification

comments.text:
+Laidee T. For some cats that may be, but my crew is doing very well with 
the Hills Prescription.
comments.author: squirrel1ification

comments.text:
Dry food is the worse choice for urinary/kidney issue. The "kidney" cat 
need to pee a lot and it would not while eating dry food. When you feed 
your cat raw meat you can - you should - give your cat accordingly the 
proper supplements. Its possible to adjust the proportions of the 
supplements to help treat the cat. One of my cats has urinary issues. We 
feed him only raw meat with supplements (BARF).
comments.author: Laidee T.

captions.text: What's up, Team Cat Mojo?

We have a special episode
of Cat Mojo today.

I field a lot of questions
about cat nutrition.
And I'm glad.

It makes me happy to be able
to talk about that body mind
connection with cats.

I've been doing that for
many, many, many years.

And for quite awhile now, one
of the tools in my toolbox

has been felinenutrition.org,
and felinenutrition.org really

gets into the nitty gritty
about what cats need to eat
and what keeps them vital.

And I'm really happy to welcome
Margaret Gates her today.

Margaret Gates is the founder
and director of the Feline

Nutrition Education Society,
and welcome Margaret.
Hi.
It's so good to see you.

Tell me a little
bit, tell the world

a little bit about
felinenutrition.org
and how you started it.

Well, I started in 2008 after
I had attended a lecture
given by a v about nutrition.

And one of the
things she did was

she brought in all her equipment
and made a batch of raw food
right there.
And I realized how easy it was.

And also how she explained
what cats evolved to eat

and what they really
should be eating,
which is a raw meat diet.

That's what their whole
systems are geared up to do.

And I switched all of my cats,
who were then about a year old,
on to a raw meat diet.

And I was just blown
away by the results.

Even with cats that
we're young and healthy,

they had more energy, their
coats got soft and silky,

and best of all, the poop
doesn't smell at all.

It's been an uphill
battle in terms

of advocating a
bio-appropriate diet for cats.

Since you started in '08,
are you finding that there is

a measure of acceptance
around raw diet?
Acceptance is growing.

Yes, the vets are
slowly coming around

and one of the
things we have found

is a lot of people start
feeding their cats the raw meat

diet after visiting our site or
deciding on their own to do it.

And they end up taking their
cats to the vet, the vets ooh

and aah over how
healthy their cats are

and we've had people it took
an 18-year-old cats that

have been on a raw meet
diet and the vet just

couldn't believe the
cat was 18 years old.

Then they reveal
what they're feeding

the cat and a lot of vets take
a step back and start really

thinking about it at that
point, because, they're

getting educated
by their clients.

Most vets don't get a lot
of education in nutrition,
and that's part of the problem.

What education they
do get is often
taught by the pet food company.
Exactly, right.

I've had vets
describe this to me.

It was mostly a course
in how to prescribe

the veterinary
prescription diet.

It wasn't about what
was best for the cat.

So a lot of vets just don't
know very much about it,

and because a vet,
they're reluctant.

Vets that are a little
bit more open minded

are willing to learn from what
their clients are showing them.

And willing to see the results,
because a raw meat diet

can be very effective in
helping cats with IVD,

and diabetes, and other
diseases, urinary tract
problems.

And because of that, a lot
of people are turning to it
and trying raw meat diets.

Tell me about your
light bulb moment.

I suddenly realized that,
of course, a cat is a cat.
They evolved to eat raw meat.

And the fact that we're
feeding them other things

is leading to a lot
of health problems.

We're feeding cats foods
that they did not evolve

and it is causing them a
lot of health problems.

Especially dry food, because
cats are obligate carnivores,

they don't have any
requirement for carbohydrates.

That's one of the things
that this vet pointed out.

And once you point
that out to people,

and they suddenly
realize what they

had been feeding their cat,
because we had fed our cats
dry food.

And once you realize that you're
feeding your cat something

that they have no
business eating,

they have no requirement for
carbohydrate, and all dry food,

no matter what the ingredients,
even if it's grain free,
is filled carbohydrates.

And that was
something I realized,

that I'd been contributing
to my cat's health problems
by what I was feeding him.

I had assumed that because
this food is in the stores

and it's available, that
it was OK for my cat.
It's not.

Everyone talks about the
fact that-- my grandma
fed her cat blank blank.

I'd feed-- my mom fed her
cats the dry blank blank,
and I feed it.

And our cats are living
to be 20 years old.
So their lifespan is just fine.

What do you say to
people who say that?

Yes, some cats do survive
into old age on dry food.

But it's still not a
healthy food for them.

They never tell you whether that
cat was having kidney problems,

whether it was having any other
medical problems, whether it
was probably overweight.

Cats are a lot
healthier when they're
eating bio appropriate diets.

Not every cat is going to have
a problem on a dry food diet.
A lot of cats well.

And you don't know when
you're starting out

whether your cat's
going to have a problem.
And I always think why risk it?

The myth that you can
feed a grain free dry.
And it's great for then.

The whole packaging of
grain free, talk to me
about that real quick.

Because people started
to avoid grains

with cats, which are very
dangerous to give cats,

manufacturers caught onto that
and started eliminating grains.

All they do is substitute
another carbohydrate,
some sort of vegetable usually.

It's still carbohydrates,
it's still dry.

Cats don't need
carbohydrates and they

need to get most of their
liquid in their food, which

is why canned or raw
diet is most important.

Tell folks how they
get this information
on feline nutrition.

If you go to
feline-nutrition.org,

we have lots of
different sections.

We have sections
on nutrition that

would talk about
these prepared diets,

we also have a recipe if
you want to make homemade,

you need to follow a recipe,
because cats need meat, bone,
and organ in their diet.
Can't just be plain meat.
That's very deficient.

And we have lots of
different articles

on how to do a proper
raw meat diet whichever
method you're using.
Thank you so much, Margaret.
You're welcome.

Me and you could sit here and
talk for six hours, I'm sure.
We could.
And hopefully we will sometime.

But in the meantime
folks, you know

how I feel about a
bio appropriate diet.

Now you're starting to see that
it's not such a strange thing.

Feline-nutrition.org,
please go to it,
you'll see the links down below.
And do what's best for your cat.
Start thinking.

Is that kibble in
that bowl really
the right thing for your cat?

You know I talk to you guys
all the time about structuring

meal time, structure meal
time, with at the very least,

a grain free wet diet,
but start taking a look

at the kind of things you'll
find with the Feline Nutrition
Education Society.
Please do it.

Do what's best for your cat
and avoid the learning curve

that a lot of us
including me and Margaret
have gone through before.

We're trying to
make it so you don't

have to make those tough
decisions once your cat is not
well.

All right, folks, if you
want to get in touch with me,

and I'm sure you
do at this point.

This is really
interesting stuff.

You can find me on Twitter and
on Facebook and on YouTube.

And you can also find
Margaret wherever you need
to on feline-nutrition.org.

Until the next time we
meet, all light, all love,
all mojo to you, love you.
Goodbye.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

title: Exactly How Diet Affects Your Cat
